Issues.Title: feat(core): rename async to asyncTest to avoid confusing
Issues.Body:
@angular/core/testing provide `async` test utility, but the name `async` is
confusing with the javascript keyword `async`. And in some test case, if you
want to use both the `async` from `@angular/core/testing` and `async/await`,
you may have to write the code like this.

```typescript
it('test async operations', async(async() => {
  const result = await asyncMethod();
  expect(result).toEqual('expected');
}));
```

So in this PR, the `async` is renamed to `asyncTest`.

we may remove this monkey patch, since it may swallow the errors when the user

Issues.Title: Unable to distinguish between different NgZones used on the same page
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

This is really about an API design flaw/limitation, so it falls somewhere between a bug and a feature request. However there is a specific situation in the upgrade package that could arguably be considered a bug.

### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package @angular/core.

### Description

`NgZone.isInAngularZone()`, is a static method, which means that it can only answer if we are currently running in any Angular Zone, rather than the one for the "current" application.

Angular has always been designed to support multiple applications running on a single page. While the CLI is not particularly conducive to this situation, that does not change this design intent. 

However, by default, each application will have its own NgZone, and underlying zone. Thus if you have two apps called App1 and App2, they will have different zones, unless you go out of your way to avoid that.

The problem is that you cannot tell which one you are running in. `NgZone.isInAngularZone()` will return true regardless of which of App1 or App2's zone you are running in. Now this is not always a particularly huge deal. That API is only used twice in angular outside the tests or assertions. The first is to print a warning message if navigation is triggered 

However, if used in a pattern like this: `NgZone.isInAngularZone() ? cb() : ngZone.run(cb)`, that is a problem, since the zone we are currently running in could be the one for App2, when the callback needs to run in the zone for App1. If that code seems at all unlikely, it shouldn't, since it came from this repository. It only runs when using `downgradeModule()`, but it is still arguably buggy:

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/d1ea1f4c7f3358b730b0d94e65b00bc28cae279c/packages/upgrade/src/common/src/downgrade_component.ts#L90

I expect a very similar pattern occurs from time to time in third party libraries, or even in application code. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
Ideally there would be an instance method on NgZone that would return true if you are running in that specific zone.

Also, ideally the existing static methods would be deprecated, in favor of new versions named something like `IsInAnyAngularZone`, to indicate that it returns true if you are in any such zone. This would encourage existing users of this api to decide if they they are concerned with running in the zone for a specific app, or if they care about running in any angular zone. For example, some code may simply want to make sure it is running outside of any angular zone for performance or correctness reasons. 

### Describe alternatives you've considered
A different possibility would be to move the zone to the platform level, and force all apps to use the same zone. That would be a big breaking change, with implications on several other apis. It also eliminates the change-detection speedup that comes from each app having their own zone.

Issues.Title: fix(core): don't consider inherited NG_ELEMENT_ID during DI
Issues.Body:
Special DI tokens like `ChangeDetectorRef` and `ElementRef` can provide a factory via `NG_ELEMENT_ID`. The problem is that we were reading it off the token as `token[NG_ELEMENT_ID]` which will go up the prototype chain if it couldn't be found on the current token, resulting in the private `ViewRef` API being exposed, because it extends `ChangeDetectorRef`.

These changes fix the issue by guarding the property access with `hasOwnProperty`.

Fixes #36235.

Issues.Title: ci(compiler-cli): exempt compiler-cli .bazel files from dev-infra approval
Issues.Body:
Previously, dev-infra approval (via PullApprove) was required for all
.bazel files in the monorepo, including those in packages/compiler-cli.

The compiler-cli package is a little special in this sense:
 * it's not shipped to NPM in the APF
 * it uses lots of internal subpackages to organize and test its code

As a result:
 * changes to compiler-cli BUILD.bazel files are not user visible and
   don't have larger implications for the packages published to NPM,
   unlike changes to other BUILD.bazel files in the repo
 * the requirement for dev-infra approval for BUILD.bazel changes is
   overly burdensome, because compiler-cli build files change more
   rapidly than those of other packages.

This commit exempts the compiler-cli's build files from the requirement
for dev-infra approval. It will be sufficient for such files to be
approved by the normal compiler reviewers.

Issues.Title: AOT Compilation drops certain functions from Route files silently
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? I am not sure ### Description I am noticing dissonant behavior between AOT compilation and JIT compilation. This in and of itself, is not the concern. The issue is that, in this particular context, AOT and JIT behave similarly but differ without compiler warnings or errors in one particular case. If I define a function on a route's `data` field, it will appear with JIT on `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.firstChild.data`. However, with AOT, it silently drops this field. No compiler error, no compiler warning. This seems to go against the precedent that has been set, wherein both AOT and JIT give compiler errors if you attempt to build with lambda expressions or non exported functions. See example code below. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Serve commands with arguments I used. ``` ng serve -c=debug ng serve -c=debug --aot ``` Example Route ``` { path: 'someroute', component: SomeComponent, pathMatch: 'full', data: { pageTitle: 'Some | Title', doesShowUpWithAOT: doesShowUpWithAOT, // throwsCompileErrorWithAndWithoutAOT: throwsCompileErrorWithAndWithoutAOT, this behaves as expected doesNotShowUpWithAOTAndDoesNotThrowCompilerError() { // behaves inconsistently between JIT and AOT console.log('foo'); }, // alsoThrowsCompilerErrorWithAndWithoutAOT: () => console.log('foo') this behaves as expected } ``` ``` // code from within some class constructor(private _route: ActivatedRoute, private _router: Router) { this._router.events .subcribe(event => { if(event instanceof NavigationEnd) { const data = this._route.snapshot.firstChild.data; const functionMember = data['doesNotShowUpWithAOTAndDoesNotThrowCompilerError']; // is null with AOT, properly defined with JIT } }) } ``` I would argue, for the sake of consistency and explicitness, that both AOT and JIT should throw compiler errors, instead of the function making it through in JIT, and dropping away silently in AOT. I believe this would save development time by cutting down on debugging. Of course, I am always open to an explanation. Thanks! ## üî• Exception or Error 



In this particular case, there is none, which what I contend the bad behavior (bug) is.

Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] serve ... and probably others ### Is this a regression? Yes. I had already reported and fixed this for angular 6 (#11833, #11834), and the fix was still working as of angular 8.0. ### Reproduction in git bash, run `ng serve`. Expected: the console output is colored (since the terminal supports that) Actual: the console output doesn't use colors ## üåç Your Environment 

     _                      _                 ____ _     ___
    / \   _ __   __ _ _   _| | __ _ _ __     / ___| |   |_ _|

                |___/


Angular CLI: 9.1.8
Node: 12.18.0
OS: win32 ia32

Angular: 9.1.11
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.901.8
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.901.8
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.901.8
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.901.8
@angular-devkit/core              9.1.8
@angular-devkit/schematics        9.1.8
@angular/cli                      9.1.8
@ngtools/webpack                  9.1.8
@schematics/angular               9.1.8
@schematics/update                0.901.8
rxjs                              6.5.5
typescript                        3.8.3
webpack                           4.42.0
## Analysis It seems that this regression was introduced by c4313f55e4412dba50a8d09c4daa4a20642b8e77. Specifically, color support checking is now done in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/1cd51e64c7331a9cc48d59e8fd6df74d3c6c48f3/packages/angular/cli/utilities/color.ts#L11-L14 Alas, when node is run within a MINGW terminal (as installed by git for windows), `process.stdout` is a `Socket`, causing `instanceof WriteStream` to return false, and all use of colors by the angular CLI to be disabled, even though the MINGW terminal supports colors just fine ... An easy fix is: ```javascript // Typings do not contain the function call (added in Node.js v9.9.0) export const supportsColor = process.stdout instanceof WriteStream && ((process.stdout as unknown) as { getColorDepth(): number }).getColorDepth() > 1 || process.env.MSYSTEM; // MINGW terminals support color even though nodejs mistakes them for a Socket ``` If desired, I can submit a PR to that effect. Alternatively, you might prefer to delegate to angular_devkit/core/src/terminal/caps.ts instead, whose vendored implementation of `supportsColor` still contains my earlier fix. However, not knowing your policy for dependencies across npm packages I don't feel comfortable submitting a PR to that effect.

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): exclude es5 bundles from being prefetch
Issues.Body:
Fixes https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/31256.

When differential loading is used, by default the Angular Service Worker will double-(pre)fetch the ES5 & ES2015 bundles, unless those are explicitly excluded as per https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/31256#issuecomment-506507021.

Excluding those ES5 bundles from the `ngsw-config.json` template would provide a better developer experience, removing the risk of double fetching the JS bundles when differential loading is used/enabled, while having no impact when differential loading isn't used.

Doing so would prevent browsers with Service Worker support but without `<script type="module">` support to prefect the correct JS bundles, but I'd argue the tradeoff is acceptable (and the default `ngsw-config.json` config can just be modified) compared to current double fetching.

In addition:
- the few browser versions that support Service Workers but not `<script type="module">`, which according to https://caniuse.com/#feat=es6-module & https://caniuse.com/#feat=serviceworkers are basically Firefox < 60 (current is 76), Chrome < 61 (current is 83), Opera < 48 (current is 68), are all outside Angular's browser support ranges (and outdated).
- the Angular Service Worker has also no support to load a different (es5) `ngsw.json` config for these browsers (nor the Angular CLI has support to built it), and realistically will never need to.

Issues.Body:

4. The selected tab not activated and the route page isn't display.
 
#### Expected Behavior

Select tabs with <kbd>Enter</kbd> or <kbd>Space</kbd> keys will activate the selected tab.

There is also a function call that should handle it. here is the [call](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/b225b875714ec4335e509b122432b29bb033708b/src/material/tabs/tab-nav-bar/tab-nav-bar.html#L12) and here is the [function](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/b225b875714ec4335e509b122432b29bb033708b/src/material/tabs/paginated-tab-header.ts#L269).

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): sometimes incorrectly swapping items at the ends of the list
Issues.Body:
The drop list has some logic that doesn't allow a swap to occur if the items being swapped are the same as the ones in the previous swap and the direction of the user's pointer hasn't changed. This is set up so that we don't trigger a swap for every pixel, if the user's pointer lands on a different item after the previous swap is done.

The above-mentioned logic can be problematic if the user takes an item from the middle, drags it out of the list and then inserts it at the end while dragging upwards. In this case the list won't allow the swap, because the item is the same as the one in the previous swap and the pointer's direction hasn't changed.

These changes resolve the issue by preventing the swap only if the user's pointer landed on the same item after the previous swap was finished.

Fixes #19249.

Issues.Title: Make MDC MatChipRow editable by connecting to the mdc web's new edit interface.
Issues.Body:
This connects MatChipRow to the new editable interface introduced in [this PR](https://github.com/material-components/material-components-web/commit/cf3b664ab1f12b17ea827ad1e2870977b9836e5b) so users can edit chips in a chip grid.

With these changes, when the "editable" input on a mat-chip-row is set to true, double clicking it or pressing enter when the chip's primary action is focused will switch it to an "editing" mode. When the user hits enter or removes focus from that chip, it will revert to its earlier state and emit the value that was modified by the user so the host components can handle updating the model.

I've also updated the demo page so developers can enable this flag there, and verified that the full test suite still passes.
